cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

R.M.S "Oroya" will leave Suez about April 6.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ophir" will leave Port Said March 26
R.M.S. “Orient" will leave Port Said April 9
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% of the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be made within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20% if return voyage be made within 6 months of arrival.

S.S. Herefordshire 7,182 tons, will leave Suez about March 29th.
S.S. Shropshire 6,755 tons, will leave Suez about April 12th.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,336 tons, will leave Port Said about March 18th.
S.S. Worcestershire 7,160 tons, will leave Port Said about April 1st.

Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL KHARTOUM, SUDAN
div.p: SUDAN.
First Class. Open all the year round.
THOROUGHLY RENOVATED AND IMPROVED.

Standing in a magnificent position in its own extensive grounds on the banks of the Blue Nile. Perfect climate, no mosquitoes, moder comfort, very homely. Concerts twice a week on the verandah of the Hotel.
ENTIRELY NEW MANAGEMENT.
For accommodation please write or wire beforehand to Manager
G. OTTO BOCK, Manager.
Lake Holland House, New York.

15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
The most charming Sea-side Residence in Egypt.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort.
Unique Situation on the Beach.

G. RUNCKEWITZ, Proprietor.

div.head: The George Nungovich Hotels
div.p: Grand Hotel, Helouan.- Finest and most luxurious Hotel near Cairo. Patronized by Royalty. Moderate charges. Special terms for residents.

Hotel des Bains.- Most comfortable hotel, opposite the Baths. Pension from P.T. 40. Attached to the above hotels and specially reserved for their clients are the Golf Links (18 holes) with English Professional. Own Golf House in the dessert.
Sulphur Bath Establishment.- Sulphur water stronger than any in Europe. Eight European Masseurs and Masseuses. Every modern improvement.

div.head: FORCE APRÈS MALADIE
div.p: De même que la plus petite graine peut donner naissance à un très grand arbre, le moindre rhume, la toux la plus légère peuvent engendrer une longue et dangereuse maladie s'ils ne sont, en temps opportun, enrayés à l'aide de l'Emulsion Scott.

Toutes affections de la gorge et la poitrine, de quelque nature et si opiniâtres, si anciennes qu'elles soient, cèdent rapidement à l'efficacité de
qui vous refait des poumons capables de résister à toute intempéries ou autres influences malfaisantes.
Quand les fièvres ou une longue et douloureuse maladie ont réduit le corps à un inquiétant état de faiblesse et d'amaigrissement, un reconstituant qui vous remettra promptement est nécessaire.
l'EMULSION SCOTT

est le meilleur fortifiant du monde: ell na pas d..... Ell stimule l'appétit et améliore promptement la digestion. Elle fait des muscles et enrichit le sang, ell .... vitalité et donne à l'organism le pouvoir de résister à la maladie. L'Emulsion Scott est autant un alanent .... remède, car ell fournit au corps affaibli ce dont il a besoin pour reprendre muscles et forces ; ses nombres..... faisant résultats sont, en vérité, surprenants. Il y a reclle...ment grand danger à perdre embonpoint et pois à l'organism, bientôt débilité, deviendrait une proie facile pour la maladie.
L'EMULSION SCOTT

contient le principe fortifiant de tous aliments ; elle arrête le déperissement et reconstitutue une chair saine. Le flaton en est toujour présenté dans une enveloppe de papier couleur saumon avec, dessus, cette gravure.
En vente chez tous Pharmaciens et Droguistes.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C.
Cairo Offices.-No. 1 Sharia Vervudachi, (opposite the Agricultural Bank.)

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
Monday, March 19, 1906.

div.head: S.P.C.A
div.p: The eleventh annual report of the Cairo branch of the S.P.C.A. contains muoh interesting information for the friends of animals and fall statistical tables which show the excellent work done during the past year both by the Cairo branch and by the affiliated branches in the provinces. The increased receipts show that the society is doing well from a financial point of view, the convictions for various forms of ornelty show & gratifying decrease, and the infirmary has been thoroughly repaired and rearra" ged. All these facts are in the highest degree satisfactory, but there are two points in the report that are not altogether pleasant reading for the humane: we refer to the apparent reluctance of the tourist to assist the society and to the growing practice of underpaying cab-drivers. Mr. Rambold, who has done so much for the society daring the last few years, writes on the latter subject with most commendable frankness. After pointing out that the condition of the cab-borses in Cairo during the past summer and autumn has been worse than at any time döring. recent years owing to the unusually high price of forage and the low tariff, he shows that owners of cab-horses will appropriate the same margin of profit as they have done in the days of cheap forage. The price of tibn and coro increases bat only the same amount is spent on feeding the horses.

Bat what aggravates the situation is the habit of systematically underpaying the cabdrivers, on which the Hon. Secretary of the Cairo branch of the S.P.C.A. bas much to say. The remarks which follow perhaps seem to constitute rather too severe an indictment of certain Earopeans of the higher class, bat we have good reason to know that they are not in the slightest degree exaggerated. Mr. Rambold says : "It is to be regretted that the practice of paying even less than the fare is occasionally followed by Englishmen and other Europeang of the higher class, who might be expected to know better. The argument that when the cabdriver is overpaid he will reserve the excess fare for himself, and not devote it to giving his animals more to eat, may possibly hold good in some cases ; bat, by slightly overpaying a cab driver, he is "given the opportunity of improving the condition of his ani: mals. If he is, ander-paid, he is deprived of all chance of doing so, unless he is willing to starve himself. The society have been unable to do more than arrest the worst cases and treat them at the Infirmary. Ao argument which, strange as it may seem, has been advanced in defence of paying the cab-driver less than his proper fare is' that, although the tariff is indicated on a plate in every cab, it has no legal sanction. This argument is as erroneous as it is unworthy. The cab-tariff in Csiro is enacted by the Governor of Cairo and approved by the Mixed Courts. It is, therefore, binding on foreigners, and, in the event of their paying less than the legal fare, the cabdrivers would have ground for an action in the Mixed Courts. It need scarcely be remarked that & recourse to this remedy is entirely beyond the means of the majority of drivers, who must be content to see themselves defrauded of their proper fare."

As for tourist donations, we feel that it is hopeless to expect much from these birds of passage. A few years ago, when beasts covered with wounds and sores horrified the sensitive nerves of the visitor to Egypt, donations were frequent enough. Nowadays the tourist realises that the neighbourhood of Shepbeard's and the Savoy Hotel is free from soola sights and is quite satisfied. The fact that brutalities, the sight of which would disgust and sicken bim, are too frequent in the villages and country towns of Egypt, does not intrude upon his serenely optimistic assumption that the S.P.C.A. has no further need of his help.

div.p: THE INDICATEUR EGYPTIEN

. Clemenceau bas arrived bere. He addressed the strikers and said that he respecter their right to strike and would send no troops as long as they remained orderly, Owing to the danger of the decomposing bodies in the Courrières minor, it is expected that the authorities will decide to wall op.the galleries containing the victims, converting them into a vast necropolis. (Reuters)
The strikers pow number 82,0 o. M. Clenenceaa, Minister of the Interior, has visited the coalfields, and recommended calm. (H.)
The Courrières minors and masters' representatives have assembled here. The masters have conceded imoreases of wages which the men will consider (Reuters)

The delegates of the strikers at Pau.de Calais and the representatives of the mining comps pies met at the Ministry of Pablio Worke. The companies agree to an increase of 10 per conta The delegates will consult the strikers. (H.)

div.head: ALGECIRAS CONFERENCE.
COMPLETE STANDSTILL.
div.p: The Conference is at a complete standstill. The Swiss authorities are greatly annoyed at the Austro-German proposal to appoint a Swiss inspector without consulting the Federation. (Reuters)

div.head: CHINESE LABOUR.
A CONTROVERSY.
div.p: Mr. Winston Churchill, writing to a correspondent, a accuses Mr. Chamberlain of causing & depreciation in Kaffir securities by lugubrious and pessimistic orations.
Mr. Winston Churchill's speech in the House of Commons, and especially his threat of veto, bus aroused indignation in South Africa. (Reuters)

Mr. Chamberlain, in a letter to the Times," in reply to Mr. Winston Churchill (mentioned on the 16th instant), accuses the Government of inconsistency regarding the Chinese and declares that any attempt to veto the Transvaal Government's decision thereanent would probably lead to a serious conflict. (R.)

div.head: EDUCATION BILL.
NON-CONFORMISTS ALARMED.
div.p: The Non-conformists are alarmed by the rumours that the Government contemplate making concessions to Catholics in their new Education Bill, and threaten to renew the agitation in a most vigorous manner if this be true. (Reuters)

div.head: TURKEY AND PERSIA.
div.p: The British and Russian Embassies ara lending their good offices to secure an equitable settlement between Turkey and Persia. (R.)

div.head: BULGARIAN BANDS AGAIN.
div.p: Bulgarian bands are commencing their crimes of depredation again. They have set fire to a Greek village and killed several people. (Havas)

div.head: TERRIBLE EARTHQUAKE IN JAPAN
div.p: A terrible earthquake has taken place at Kagi. Several hundred buildings have been destroyed and many hundreds of persons have been killed or injured. (Reuter)

div.head: FLOODS IN BRAZIL.
div.p: Over 50 men have been killed and many injured owing to landslides and foods in Brazil. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIA AND JAPAN.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, March 17. The report is denied that the Tsar is sending a Grand Duke to Japan. (Reuter)

div.head: SEVASTOPOL MUTINY.
div.p: The sentence on Lieutensnt Schmidt connected with the Sevastopol mutiny, has been commuted to being shot instead of being hanged. (Reuter)

div.head: ST. PATRICK'S DAY.
div.p: St. Patrick's Day was celebrated with the customary enthusiasm, and by concerts and parades of the Irish regiments. Shamrock was universalily worn in London. (Reuter)

div.head: CENSUS OF GERMAN EMPIRE.
div.p: The census of the German Empire shows a population of 60,605,183 (Reuter)

div.head: INTERNATIONAL FOOTBALL
div.p: Association. Scotland beat Ireland by one to nil.
Rugby. England beat Scotland by 9 to 8. (Reuter)
